titlestmt.sponsor: This collection-level EAD record is a product of the Philadelphia Area Consortium of Special Collections Libraries (PACSCL) Consortial Survey Initiative, which was funded by the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: Machine-readable finding aid generated in EAD from data in the PACSCL Consortial Survey Database on 12/21/2012. Modified by Dot Porter in 2017.

bioghist.p: Emily Grace was a graduate of Bryn Mawr College, receiving her BA in 1933 and her master's in 1934. She received a doctorate from Yale on the literary sources for the history of Sparta in the 3rd century BC. In 1949 she and her husband, Vladimir Kazakevich, moved to Moscow, where she worked for the Institute of Ancient History at the Academy of Sciences of the USSR, and continued her own work on 4th and 5th century Greek law. She returned to the US in 1986 and took a fellowship at Bryn Mawr. She died in 1987.

scopecontent.p: This collection consists of an unpublished manuscript and notes for a monograph entitled "The non-citizen offenser in attic and platonic Homicide Law" written by Emily Grace. The work is in English and Russian. The papers include: index card research notes in Greek, English, Russian, and German; manuscript chapters with annotations; and correspondence with other scholars. The collection also contains English and Russian reprints of Grace's articles, correspondence with family, and a small collection of correspondence between Virginia Grace and Michael Jameson about Grace's work.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
